text: Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, man, no, we don’t take out anywhere close to your entire blood volume. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just like this much but to do that they have to sort of strain for the right cells. That’s why you’re hooked up to this machine that they have for like two and a half three hours. So, I always say, you know, bring something to read. They play movies. If you have to pee a lot, you bring a urinal so you don’t have to get up because if nurses will start screaming if you move and um there’s two ways. Like you have pretty good veins so um most of the time they can just do it straight from your veins. Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: They’ll tell us whether that’s possible. A bunch of other people you need a port for six weeks where they actually put it in your arm or your chest and they remove the stuff, you know, out and then when we’re done we pull it out. Now, go like this and you know that your veins are there. They’re not spectacular veins but I don’t think they’re terrible veins. So, it’s like three hours for us to do that procedure and then when you get it reinfused back on a Thursday this stuff comes back in a bag and you get it through Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: the IV it’s about an hour. How’s that for fancy. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That’s FDA approved for a cool, hundred thousand dollars so your insurance has to say yes number one, now don’t look at me with those eyes of yours. Secondly, we help you through that so that’s on us and if it’s not approved you won’t get it because people can’t, there’s no way we can afford that so we just would leave that but I might just start there to see if we can get the insurance to cover it. Most insurances will cover it, most insurances. So, that’s one. Patient: Uh-huh. Doctor: Now, the study that goes with that it isn’t whether you get the medicine or not, that’s a done deal, our study is to know what happens to your immune system so every time we see you we take ah blood from you so that we measure. Okay, what is this guy who’s supposed to fight this kind of infection. What’s his level? And what about this gal’s cell? What was she supposed to do? You know, it’s like who’s sleeping on the job Patient: mm hmm.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I kind of do think that a hormone therapy is sort of inevitable for you. Um the other question that you asked was about using chemotherapy. I presume that you’re asking whether that was either given by itself or maybe in combination with hormone therapy like as a clumped – double therapy. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is -

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: If you decided to participate in a different clinical trial, then, of course, you could receive that therapy here as long as K___ approved of you to enroll in that trial, which they probably will, because their general policy is if you’re participating in a trial at an institution that’s not available through K___, then they support that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So you could definitely still be our patient, and we would love it if you were. Uh, we’ve gotten to know you for the past several months, and I think your experience with us has also been relatively good. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so, you know, that could be a win-win, but we have to make sure that it’s something that makes sense for you. We’re not going to put you on a trial just for the sake of keeping you at H___. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it just might be that we have something that really does look interesting or promising that we can offer you. I don’t want to go into those details today because I don’t know when that time will come or if it will come. But if that time comes, when we’re deciding between a standard therapy, like the two that I mentioned, or a different experimental therapy, I can give you the consent form, and you can think about it, and if you decide to participate that would be through us. Patient: Um hum. Okay. Because I know the discussion we had initially, uh, was the chemo. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That was one of the options. And I used the word, chemo bad. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s bad in terms, you know, the side effects are worse than everything you’ve had so far.

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

text: Patient: I don’t know, I…maybe it’s age. Doctor: You’re not that old yet. (laughs) Patient: Oh. (chuckles) Doctor: That’s young, in this day and age. Patient: Yeah. Uh-huh. Doctor: Any other new symptoms? So fatigue is maybe a bit worse? Patient: I feel so; I, I uh I govern that by my ability to you know do things around the house. So whether it’s supporting activities, playing golf I don’t have any energy. And possibly because I’m a little heavier now, too. I’ve gained a few pounds. Doctor: Now are you still trying to be as active as possible, for example, golf or other activities? Or has that been slowing you down? Patient: I’m trying, but I just don’t have the energy. Doctor: Okay, uh any other issues with hot flashes or night sweats? Patient: No, no. Not night sweats, but I do recognize that at times I’m sitting in church and for some reason I just start where other folks are you know are just perfectly calm and cool. Doctor: So during the day just out of the blue? Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops.

text: Patient: Um. Doctor: Did, uh, did she get tested for it? Family Member: She did not get tested, but Doctor: Okay. Family Member: But, uh, E_’s gonna want to know. Patient: My daughter who just had this, our third grandson, would, I’m sure would want to know. Family Member: I’m sure for E_. Patient: Uh, so we have one granddaughter, E_, and two grandsons. Um. My, my youngest daughter deals with a lot of, uh, medical issues. Um. Uh. Anything else? Doctor: So, my advice, my advice is that um they should all get tested. Because this is a gene that, you know, there’s a lot of genes that we’re doing mutation tests and a lot of them, we don’t even know how predisposing it is to cancer for you - let alone if somebody inherits it. But, this is the one that we know if you have this, it predisposes you to getting cancer. And, that’s why I said, it’s a genie out of the bottle, because some people just don’t wanna know. They don’t wanna know that they’re –- Family Member: Why? Their children! Wouldn’t they want to get tested? Doctor: No, the children don’t want to know? Family Member: They don’t? Doctor: Well. I’m leaving that to you – you’re going to have to have a discussion with them to say, you know.

text: Patient: Yeah, I’ll just stick with the prednisone. Doctor: Okay. And you can definitely try cutting back on the dose okay because as you saw in the scans, remember last time I had given you a slight inkling that it was heading starting to grow back? Patient: Yes. Doctor: And when we did the recent scans are showing a continued slight increase. So it’s a small increase, the bone scan is still completely okay and so you do not have the spread to the bone that we can see. Patient: Yeah, right, right. Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

Doctor: Uh because of that I think we should stop this treatment. Okay because you’ve sort of gotten the benefit you’re going to get out of it and it may be time to move on to other treatment. Now in terms of other treatments what to go to next? And uh there is a medication that is something called Niraparib okay. And it’s sort of this family of medications called barhabiters. And the way they work is if your cancer expresses certain specific mutations, they it’s likely to be effective. So if you treat everybody with your kind of prostate cancer on this medication, the chances of it working were wherever fifty to twenty percent, so pretty low. When we looked at just the people with those mutations that were expressed in the cancer, then the response went up to seventy eighty percent. So what we’re doing… Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
